Two linear equations

You may have noticed that so far that the equations we have dealt with have been linear, meaning they are degree one polynomials. These are the simplest type of simultaneous equations and actually there are two main methods we can use to solve them. These methods are called elimination and substitution. In the examples below we will go through how to use both methods.


The method of substitution is most easily used when at least one equation is given with either \(x\) or \(y\) as the subject of the equation. The idea is to substitute this expression for this variable into the other equation. In contrast, the method of elimination is most easily used when the two equations are given in the form \(ax + by = c\). In this method we make the coefficients of \(x\) or \(y\) to be the same size by multiplying either one or both of the equations. We can then subtract one of the equations from the other, which has the effect of eliminating either the \(x\) variables or the \(y\) variables.
